title: PSA: If its INTENTIONALLY left in the game it is no longer a "bug"
body:
It is no longer a bug if its been left in on purpose. It's not a  "bug" if its intentionally being left in the game.

{{champion:92}}'s animation canceling is no longer a bug and she's balanced around having it

{{champion:64}}'s ward hop is no longer a bug and he's balanced around having it

{{champion:79}}'s Flash -> Bodyslam is no longer a bug and he's balanced around having it

{{champion:69}}'s Ult -> Flash is no longer a bug and she's balanced around having it

Etc, etc. The list goes on.

Already know this thread is doomed because I mentioned certain champs without tar and feathering them. Oh well.

While i see what you're saying that still doesn't change the definition of a "bug"
http://i2.kym-cdn.com/photos/images/newsfeed/000/909/991/48c.jpg?noredirect
A computer bug is an error in the coding that causes an unintended result. If it is now an intentional result, it is no longer a bug.

It's still an unintentional result, just one that's being intentionally left in the game.

The result of an unintentional action does not change the fact that it was unintentional. Penicillin was an unintentional discovery, it's now manufactured intentionally, that still doesn't change the fact that it was an unintentional discovery.

Riven's animation cancelling and Lee's ward hops are still bugs regardless of if they're being left in the game intentionally because that wasn't the original intention of the code.

Yeah, like {{champion:103}}  charm interrupting dashes, {{champion:31}}  and {{champion:1}}  w following targets, {{champion:76}} being able to use her melee aa reset as a ranged attack by stance-swapping rapidly, etc...

The problem with that line of thinking is that Riot fixes bugs based on how much of a priority they think they are and how many resources they would consume, rather than how long they've been around - too many times the community has long decided that a given "bug" was working as intended, when Riot suddenly and arbitrarily decided that it was worthy of their attention.

I mean, really, do you seriously think that {{champion:48}} pillar being able to interrupt **_allied_** channels (including things like recalls, {{champion:20}} ult, {{champion:9}} ult,  and {{champion:90}} ) is working as intended, and that {{champion:48}} has been pain-stakingly balanced around it? Or do you think it's more along the lines of "Oh shit creating this terrain bugs the hell out and traps people if you let it spawn inside of them, I guess I'll just make it forcibly nudge them to the side" and nobody has gotten around to correcting the fact that it functions as cc?

Personally, I think it's the latter.

I got tired of explaining to people that Riven's entire design from the start was based on fighting games, and thus combos via animation canceling, as animation canceling is a core mechanic in fighting games. People got out of hand when it came to claiming Riven's animation canceling was an unintended bug that Riven mains were exploiting, despite knowing nothing of her design process or origin.

Uh, no it wasn't. The fighting game influence on her was mainly focused on her passive and 3 cast Q.  So she has incentive to weave autos between casts and her Q was meant to give a combo attack feel to her kit, since you could also weave her other spells between casts.

Animation canceling was an unintended effect due to spaghetti code, that Riot decided wasn't cost effective to fix.  It actually wasn't even an issue at first because before she was purely strong off of her stats and specific items (Fortitude cheese), but over time of nerfing her to a more balanced state and the rework of Tiamat and addition of ravenous hydra making it much easier to exploit the bug, it became a problem. Because it became a problem she had to be nerfed even more.  That is why she is in the state she is now where as a base champion she is pretty shitty, but if a experienced main is playing her she is godawful to face.

That is why she is in the state she is now where as a base champion she is pretty shitty, but if a experienced main is playing her she is godawful to face.

You DO know how comboing in fighting games work right? They've been using animation canceling as a core mechanic waaay back when it was **actually** a bug in like the street fighter II days in 1991. Back then, they decided it worked out better with it so they kept it and every single fighting game that came after implemented it as a core gameplay mechanic and balanced around it, taking it away and adding it as needed as well when it was deemed unhealthy. (Illaoi and Rengar anyone?)

So how you can tell me that a character released in 2011 that was based on fighting games was not intentionally supposed to use their core mechanic of animation canceling since 1991 of all things is far beyond me. You just can't tell me they "just so happened" to run into the same bug unintentionally as they did way back 20 years earlier while also referencing the genre that practically institutionalized the use of animation canceling as a gameplay design point. 

Its actually ludicrous that people insist on the idea that animation canceling was not intentional and was an exploit. Its like you guys are actively refusing to knowledge some core truths in the place of what would be the most convenient for your view. 

Riven was based off fighting games, which have been using animation canceling for over two decades. There is not possible way you can actively reference something then just kinda accidentally run into the 20 year hallmark game mechanic of fighting games. 

Riven's animation canceling was intentional from the start.

It wasn't. If you look back at all the old stuff from her release, there is no mention of animation canceling at all. It wasn't even a thing until she was balanced and people were trying to find an edge on her.  Even then it still didn't become prevalent until the tiamat change and addition of ravenous hydra.

Yes, animation canceling is a core mechanic of fighting games, but they have no place in a game like league. Most other cases of animation canceling are removed, because they cause problems.  There are exceptions, like any champion that can exploit Tiamat spaghetti code (others can, Riven is just the most famous).  Those tend to be ones that are not cost effective to fix or not easy or consistent to proc.  In the case of Riven her base stats were dumpstered so she wasn't broken in the hands of those mains who were exploiting the bug and will be just like yorick and heimerdinger before her left to rot for years before they actually fix anything.
